content.description:
This is one of Sunset's truly outstanding routes.  It has a little of everything: roofs to pull, crack climbing, face climbing.  It's a long line on beautiful, well-protected rock. 

  A bouldery start powers you through a blocky roof to a ledge.  Follow a crack system to another roof about midway; after pulling the roof, continue with face climbing to the top.  Make generous use of runners to avoid rope drag.  A 60-meter rope is just enough to make the rap.
content.protection: Mostly small to medium nuts and cams, though some larger gear can be helpful in the lower roof section.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts around the corner right of Freedom Chimney, about a 20-minute walk from the trail split.

content.description: Climb the blocks on the left side of the vertical gully.  Master a bulge (crux) and move up to a very thin and completely runout face (2nd crux) for the last 20 feet or so.  Unprotected jug haul for the last 5-10 feet.  Very heady lead.  Clean path through lichen on both sides shows the way.
content.protection: Gear to 2", but most of the gear will be under 1 inch.
content.location: Start 10' right of Blonde Ambition (30' right of the Giant's Niche).  Use rap rings at the top of Blonde Ambition to descend.

content.description: From the ledge, face climb to a left-facing corner, then up to the shallow roof below a wide crack.  Follow the big crack to the top.
content.protection: Some wide gear.  Up to about a 4 Camalot.  Anchors on top
content.location: Starts on a spacious ledge just left of Train Time.  Look for the obvious wide crack in the roof up high, almost dead in the middle of Celebrity Flake.

climbs.name: Unnamed Dihedral Flake
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by J Hollada, V Draper , 7/2020

content.description:
Shallow, left facing dihedral at the far right end of this section of wall. Large detached flake wedged in place leads to obtuse dihedral guarded by hollow sounding flake.  Stem through corner to low angle bulge capped by pocketed easy roof. Lichened crack leads straight up or move left to ledge and up short headwall to trees.

 Because of dubious rock quality, this gem was top-roped by walking from previous route.

 Below this corner, down a tall step and through a foliage wormhole leads to Beauty and the Beast, Divinity Crack and the Deck Party area.
content.protection: Top Rope
content.location: 20 feet right of Squirrel Fritter

content.description: Do you like thin cracks? Do you like thin gear that's solid, but hard to place? Good, then this is your climb. Start about 5 feet right of Train Time and head straight up to the thin crack/ right facing corner. Build a nest of cams below the first crux because it comes at you fast and placing additional gear would be difficult. After this is the next and hardest crux. Dink in some small wires and a black alien and get moving. Punch through this section and get pro later. Meet up with Train Time to the anchors.
content.protection: For the cruxes take doubles of your smallest cams and small nuts
content.location: Celebrity Flake, about 5 feet right of Train Time.   They both share the same anchors

content.description: Climb a steep face to a right-arching shallow corner.  Follow the arch to its end, then move right to more thin face climbing and fire for the top.  Very fun!
content.protection: Standard "Sunset" rack...heavy on the thin stuff.  A small arsenal of Aliens does the job great.  Shares bolted anchors with Walk in the Park.
content.location: Scramble up to the Celebrity Flake ledge and look for thin crack systems leading to an obvious right-leaning corner; starts about 10' right of Walk in the Park.

content.description: Climb up toward the left facing corner, passing it on the left. Crunch up through some lichen to the overhang, and pull through it at the crack. Continue to a tree belay at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: standard rack, a skinny tree at the top can be used to rap back down (or you can go exploring)
content.location: At the far south end of Sunset South, to the left of the popular beginner climb Airbrush. Look for a short, obtuse, left-facing corner about 30 feet up. Above that is a short overhang split by a crack.

climbs.name: Temple of Doom
climbs.fa: Rob Robinson with Gene Smith. Mid 80's

content.description: Stiff moves off the ground lead to better purchase once you gain good jams as well as stems on the opposite wall. Continue up the sweet handcrack until upward progress becomes impossible (you'll know when you get there). Traverse/squirm/thrutch right fighting claustrophobia until you can get gear just before you pop out of the squeeze a couple of body lengths before the anchors on Backstreet Revelations.
content.protection: Finger to hand sized cams
content.location: 20 feet uphill (climbers left) of Backstreet Revelations

content.description:
Experienced leaders have gotten a rude awakening on Sunset Sonata, which gets an old-school 5.8 rating in the DCA.  Sparse footholds for stemming make the dihedral a real workout. 

  Start in a blocky, overhung corner.  Move up to a ledge then right to a right-facing dihedral with a handcrack.  Climb the dihedral to the top.
content.protection: Small-to-medium cams; ring anchors at the top.
content.location: Starts on a ledge above the main trail, just left of the Windwalker/Liberty Bell area.

content.description: Clamber up easy ground to the start of the vertical crack. Who's Crying Now? Things get steep and sustained once you start up the crack. Be Good to Yourself and take advantage of the many opportunities to place protection Any Way You Want It. Don't Stop Believin' as you keep Lovin', Touchin', Squeezin' great finger locks and jams all the way to the top of the crack. Continue up easier ground above to where bolted anchors await you with Open Arms.
content.protection: light rack, bolted anchors w/rings at the top
content.location: On a section of wall set back from the trail a bit. The best way up leaves the main trail a little way climber's left of the Windwalker area, and meets up with the right end of the wall around Dreamway and Sunset Sonata. From there walk left around the corner, and look for the obvious short crack that heads up the wall just to the right of a tree growing near the cliff.

climbs.name: Squirrel Crack
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by J Hollada, V Draper 2019

content.description: Follow crack system into a short dihedral, then exit through a crack in a small bulge and follow chimney to top.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #4. Use trees for anchor at top, rappel from tree to get down
content.location: Ten feet to the right of Raccoon dihedral, the next crack in the face.

content.description:
Aptly named, Squeeze Box will test your skills in tight chimney climbing -- or at least getting into the chimney. 

  Starting in the alcove under the obvious wide roof crack, climb blocky ground to a narrow notch.  Worm through the notch, then prepare for the business:  finding a way into the bombay chimney above.  After the resulting thrash, continue up through easier ground on a dirty slab to the top.
content.protection: Passive/active pro in the small to medium range.  Build a gear anchor at the top.
content.location: The last route in the Sunset South section proper.  Starts in the roofed alcove about 30' right of Airbrush.  Rap off a tree at the top.

content.description: Wander up lichen covered rock passing left facing dihedral and tree midway.  Pull through bulges onto excellent face climbing to exit crack.
content.protection: Standard Sunset rack with doubles in hand sizes, two bolt anchor.
content.location: 25 feet right of Mercenary Territory

climbs.name: Southern Fried Possum
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by J Hollada, V Draper 2019

content.description: Face climb on incut plates to access a right facing dihedral and pull this short, slightly spicy crux. Above, when faced with a pair of cracks, follow the left one.  Steeper pocketed horizontals guard the top.
content.protection: Horizontal pockets protect the start, a very small cam beneath the roof and small stoppers in the dihedral protect the crux.  Standard rack of mid to large for everything else.  Sling and biners on a tree anchor
content.location: Ten feet right of Armadillo, directly below a small roof and short dihedral.

climbs.name: Skunk Fritter
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by J Hollada, V Draper 7/2020

content.description: Right facing dihedral at the far right end of RoadKill Buttress.  Follow crack in corner passing right of newly trimmed tree to follow crack features on lichened face that widen into sloped elephant's ass finish.
content.protection: Mid-size gear up to #4.  Healthy tree at top for anchor and easy rappel.
content.location: Last right facing corner past roofs and rock bench, pine tree near top of corner.

content.description:
Work through a bulge down low and then to finger crack up high. 

  There are several good climbs in this little nook. Don't miss Golden Years.
content.protection: Standard rack
content.location: Located in a recessed alcove known as the Treasure Chest; starts about 5' left of Dodge City.

content.description: A great climb with multiple cruxes, a variety of climbing and great gear.  Climb the very thin start, through some bulges, up a short finger crack, a few delicate moves lead to a stance before the final roof move.
content.protection: Lots of runners and thin gear.  Ring anchors at the top.
content.location: Located on the "Northwest Buttress" before the Giant's Niche/Blonde Ambition area.  Look for the thin start.

content.description:
Second Sun is a full-value 5.9 that gets a well-deserved three stars in the DCA.  Occasionally strenuous stances for placing pro mean you better be solid at the grade to lead this route. 

  A somewhat slabby start moves into a short, shallow dihedral, then to thin moves over a bulge.  Continue up to a small roof; pull the roof move and follow another dihedral to a more juggy finish.
content.protection: Small to medium nuts and cams.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts just left of Blonde Ambition.

climbs.name: Pigs in Space
climbs.fa: Rob Robinson, Forrest Gardner, Walter Forbes (FFA) - 1980

content.description:
This is the obvious splitter on the right side of "Pigs Buttress"--the next formation right of Celebrity Flake. 

  Sweet overhanging jams at the top.  Classic.
content.protection:
Standard Sunset, heavy on the thin stuff. 

  Rings on top
content.location: Start on the left side of Pigs Buttress in some obvious dihedrals then work right towards the pretty finger crack.

content.description: Grunt up a slot to the obvious 3-4" "Pancake" flake.   Lieback and jam through fun, albeit somewhat dirty moves.
content.protection: Some wide stuff, perhaps to 4".  There is a fixed pin above the squeeze chimney.
content.location: 20' right of Train Time on the Celebrity Flake.  Ring anchors on top.

content.description: A thought provoking thin and shallow crack with some small face holds, that somehow also houses a lone undercling (crux) Lead up to a jug rail about 25' high. Get another good piece in and crank through a few more good long horizontals until you can get underneath the hand crack. Make a committing but solid hero move into the crack and appreciate the smooth lichened wall while you shuffle up to a nice seat overlooking the valley.
content.protection:
Small up to #2 Camalot. Pick from a handful of tree anchors (I went left for the good seat and rapped back down) 

  GEAR BETA: 

  A .75 protects the first moves down low and a .4 would be a good second piece, but getting to that second piece will be some work. small nut/.1 as a good hanging piece to figure out beta. Might want to double up on.4-.75 for this guy.
content.location: This route is on the right side of Beauty and Beast area(left and up the trail from Windwalker), to the right of Divinity Crack. Dark, licheny face in front of a small tree. There is a thin shallow crack that leads to a few horizontals, up to a final hand jam crack [right most, the middle crack up high is an 11].

content.description: One of the least climbed routes here. The first pitch doesn't register on the fun factor scale, but the second pitch is super fun, exposed, great holds and excellent protection. To start, climb past a large pine tree to a ledge. Follow right-facing dihedral and step left to a belay 50 feet. Pitch 2, Follow steep crack in lichened wall. At bulge step left and follow short crack 60 feet. There is a direct finish 10b. Rather than stepping left, finish directly over the bulge at the top of pitch two.
content.protection: Bring a set of nuts, small tricams and some TCUs. You might also carry a .75 or #1 cam. Anchors at top.
content.location: Located on the Northwest Buttress and 100 feet right of Pigs in Space. It is 25 minutes from the trail split.

content.description: Leftmost on the Bunny Buttress, climb a 25' juggy chimney to a spacious ledge with a tree.  Place a directional and proceed up a steeper 15 face on the right to a tree anchor. Great first lead.
content.protection: Protection abounds with lots of opportunity for creativity. Watch out for loose pieces.
content.location: Roughly 100 right of Rude Awakening turn left just after the rock marked July 47 in yellow paint to find the "Bunny Buttress". Scramble 10 up to a right facing 40 wall of stacked blocks.  There are four beginner routes here.

content.description: 45 right of Silent Runner. Look for the obvious gap in the roof with a small tree in it. Crux is pulling through the gap in the roof while fighting with the tree.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. Bolted anchors at the top

climbs.name: Mama Raccoon
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by V Draper, J Hollada 2019

content.description: Stem your way through a beautiful right facing dihedral and a leaning crack above. Great beginner leader route!
content.protection: Standard rack up to #4, maybe some bigger stuff if you want. Slings and biners on a tree at top.
content.location: Ten feet past Chipmunk. Right facing dihedral at end of the first section of the Roadkill Buttress.

climbs.name: Lizard Pie
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by V Draper, J Hollada 6/2020

content.description:
Start on lower bench to reach starting jugs, boulder over cruxy bulge to access crack system and follow to top passing small pine midway up the face.  

 *Alternate start 10 ft to the right behind tree. Climb to horizontal jugs and move left to access vertical crack.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #4, tree anchor at top
content.location: 15 feet right of Squirrel, under head high roof, use lower bench to get started.

content.description:
Tucked away in a little alcove near the end of the Black Magic Buttress section, Little Pearl is a short but fun route.  It doesn't get much traffic, probably because of the excellent neighboring lines in the Treasure Chest section, but it's definitely worth doing if you're in the area.  Little Pearl is also a good way to get to the top of climbs like Dodge City or Sinsophrenia and set up a toprope if you're not up to leading them. 

  Starting in the shady alcove, follow the left-facing corner up to a right-leaning flake.  Layback the big flake, then on to the top.
content.protection: Mostly medium to large gear, up to 5".  Anchor using trees at the top.
content.location: Starts around the corner left of Confederate Arete in an obvious corner.

content.description:
We were a little confused as to where to start this one. There are two cracks splitting the bulging wall at the start. I'll provide directions for both. 

  P1-the easy way: Take the right crack, which leads up to a substantial tree about 30 feet up. This is the same start as Northwest Conversion. When you get in the neighborhood of the tree, start angling left and up. There's a pine tree underneath the arete that marks the left end of the upper headwall. That's generally where you're headed. (60 feet, 5.6) 

  P1-the hard way: Take the left crack. Struggle through the bulge on disappointing holds. Once things ease off, continue up and slightly left toward the pine tree mentioned in the "easy way" description above. (50 feet, 5.10) 

  P2-the main event: Start off a big block/ledge, maybe 20 feet right of the pine tree. Monkey your way up and slightly right through a series of overhangs. Surmounting the last overhang deposits you on a flat, vertical white face sprinkled with lichen. A hand crack almost immediately closes down to a finger crack that drifts in and out of existence as it works its way up the face. Fight the urge to chicken out to the Northwest Conversion crack 15 feet to your right. 25 feet of technical and sustained climbing leads you up the face. Finish on easier ground through a large flared crack loaded with dinner plate jugs, about 10 feet left of the Northwest Conversion anchors. (70 feet, 5.10)
content.protection:
Standard rack will do fine. This thing takes stoppers like they're going out of style. 

  The route tops out maybe 8 feet or so left of the bolted anchors for Northwest Conversion. From those anchors, a single rappel with a 60m rope will just reach the ground.
content.location:
On the Northwest Buttress, a little ways climber's left from the Silent Runner area. Look for a wall that starts off with a bulging overhang off the trail, then rounds over after about 20ft to low angle stuff. There's a noticeable tree growing out of the wall about 30 feet up. Up higher, things steepen into a beautiful white headwall. 

  This route eventually takes you up the left end of the higher headwall.

content.description:
Similar to neighboring Wind Walker, Liberty Bell is an excellent long route on great rock.  The bouldery start (tougher than the similar moves on Wind Walker) is the crux. 

  A tough and awkward overhanging start leads to well-protected easier face climbing through a crack system, past a pine tree, to the top.
content.protection: Medium gear (cams, tricams, nuts).  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Starts just right of Wind Walker.

content.description: Work your way up and left across the face to vertical crack system, past a pine tree, over flakes, pulling a small overhang and up to the anchors
content.protection: A selection of nuts and cams will probably cover you.  Long slings.
content.location: Just left of Blonde Ambition and Second Sun.

content.description: Climb...yes...you guessed it "Jugs" following the path of least resistance, working your way to the left and right of the rounded arete.
content.protection: Standard rack, runners.  Rap rings at the top.
content.location: Left side arete of the "Celebrity Flake".

content.description: Rightmost climb on the Bunny Buttress.  Climb up the right side of the cave wall, then trend left to a ledge. Continue up through a notch to the top of Bountiful Barnacles.  Dont pull out the loose rocks!
content.protection: Ample, but watch out for loose blocks.  Shares a tree anchor with Bountiful Barnacles.
content.location: 15 right of Bountiful Barnacles, to the right of the obvious cave.   Roughly 100 right of Rude Awakening turn left just after the rock marked July 47 in yellow paint. Scramble 10 up to a right facing 40 wall of stacked blocks.  There are four beginner routes here.

content.description: Third climb on the Bunny Buttress.  Climb up the overhanging left side of the cave wall.  Pull a bulge to the ledge and join Jenga Tower.
content.protection: Ample, but watch out for loose blocks!  Tree Anchor shared with Bountiful Barnacles.
content.location: 10 right of Bountiful Barnacles, to the left of the obvious cave.   Roughly 100 right of Rude Awakening turn left just after the rock marked July 47 in yellow paint. Scramble 10 up to a right facing 40 wall of stacked blocks.  There are four beginner routes here.

content.description: Powerful boulder start stays right of overgrown crack. (Similar to but more difficult than opening moves on Liberty Bell or Wind Walker.)  Good stance above to catch your breath then follow hand crack to short left facing dihedral. Second crux is double hand jam to pull through overhang next to large pine tree. Easy crack climbing above widening from hands to fists then off-width to top.
content.protection: Standard Sunset rack, small cams protect roof, doubles in .75 - #4 Camalot.   No anchors, top out leaving #2 as directional and traverse right along edge, slinging medium tree on the way to Wind Walker anchors.
content.location: 20ft left of Wind Walker.

content.description: Climb trough a low roof with excellent holds over the lip (crux) then move left to gain a crack with excellent jams to the anchors
content.protection: Some small pro down low opens up to hand and fist sizes up high
content.location: On the Back side of the Celebrity flake Just left around the corner from jug mania.

content.description: Pass a small roof, wiggling a small cam in horizontal pocket from a decent stance. Continue up a steep face past two well placed bolts.  Stay left of crack on thin face and friction moves to finish on Agrippa anchors.
content.protection: Small cams, two bolts
content.location: 5' left of Agrippa

content.description: Start at the triangular shaped opening. Climb to the apex of the triangle into an awkward right facing corner (crux). Get some gear in while feeling like this seems awful hard for 5.8, then head up to a small cave. Go around the block to the right and then bust left to the anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack. 2 bolt anchor at the top
content.location: Set back a little from the trail. Look for the obvious triangle shaped opening

content.description: Dodge City climbs a nice corner/hand crack, located in the alcove, right of Sinsophrenia.  Be warned there is a pebbly section.
content.protection: Trad rack - medium stuff.  Rap anchors located at the top.
content.location: Located in the Treasure Chest alcove with Sinsophrenia, above the main trail.  This alcove provides a nice cool spot for climbing.

content.description:
This one is worth a trip up the hill. 

  Pull an overhanging boulder problem off the ground to get established in the crack, which soon turns into an offwidth in a right-facing corner. The corner is capped by a roof. Watch the crack at the lip of the roof, it can be a rope pincher. 

  Above the roof, a hand crack eventually widens into a chimney that ends by a tree on a ledge. From here, continue up easy ground on the right to a larger tree at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: A #5 or #6 Camalot C4 is nice to have for the wide section. Otherwise, a standard rack. There's a stout tree at the top for rappelling.
content.location: Between the Dodge City area and the Windwalker area, on a section of white wall set far back above the cliffside trail. There's an obvious vertical crack that splits the middle of the wall. A faint trail/bushwhack heads more or less straight up there from the main trail. (Watch out for poison ivy!) Or you can take the better trail on the right side near Windwalker, and then walk over left from Sunset Sonata, Dreamway, etc.

content.description: Climb moderate (5.10) terrain to the base of the roof and plug some gear. Get psyched for puzzling feet first sequences as you boulder out the roof. Once established on the face, more 5.10 climbing takes you up good holds and a lichen covered face to the top.
content.protection: A single rack from about .2-#4 BD should get you up just fine. Fixed wires at the base of the roof to aid cleaning. Cord with a steel rap ring around a tree at the top for anchors, placed 9/14.
content.location: This route climbs the obvious crack system out the left of side of the Giant's alcove.

content.description:
Although most guidebooks have this climb listed as a 5.9, I don't know anyone who has climbed it who thinks it's that hard. If you can climb 5.8 elsewhere at Sunset, this one shouldn't give you any problems. 

  Climb some right-facing flakes up to a small overhang with a small tree above it. Pull over and head left of the tree toward a right-facing corner above. The corner is capped by another overhang, and above that good holds will lead you upward to an exit crack at the top of the cliff.
content.protection:
standard rack, bolts w/rings at the top 

  Although not required for toproping, 4 ft. slings to extend the anchor will save your rope some abuse and ensure you have enough rope to reach the ground.
content.location: To the left of the Giant's Niche -- the large archway to the left of the Blonde Ambition area. Looking at the wall to the left of the arch, there's an obvious right-facing corner system about halfway up. That's the middle of the route.

content.description: Pull an overhang and climb a blunt, rounded arete, continue just right of arete to two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Small to medium stuff, fixed pin no longer there
content.location: Arete left of Sinsophrenia

content.description: Start as for Dodge City.  Step right to a ledge.  Climb the conglomerated-rock-full-of-pebble hand crack.  Continue up to the anchors.
content.protection: Trad.  Rap rings at the top.  Optional tape for hands... pebbly
content.location: The Treasure Chest.

climbs.name: Chipmunk Arete
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by J Hollada, V Draper 2019

content.description: Face climb on great incut holds using both sides of the rounded arete. At ledge when faced with a pair of cracks, follow the right crack system to top.
content.protection: Standard rack. Slings and biners on tree at the top
content.location: Ten feet right of previous route. This section of cliff ends at this arete, route begins on the left face and follows path of least resistance up the corner.

content.description: Second climb on the Bunny Buttress. Climb the dusty and crusty arête.  Should clean up with some use.  Trend right to a tree anchor.
content.protection: Ample. No slings on the tree yet, but I'll leave some next time I'm there.
content.location: 6 right of Nickis Climb on the ledge.   Roughly 100 right of Rude Awakening turn left just after the rock marked July 47 in yellow paint. Scramble 10 up to a right facing 40 wall of stacked blocks.  There are four beginner routes here.

content.description: This sustained moderate is a three-star classic, with solid protection and fun moves all the way.  One of the best for the grade at Sunset -- don't miss it!Start with face climbing to a small overhang, then follow a crack system to the top.
content.protection: Small to medium gear.  Bolted anchors.
content.location: Starts about 10' right of Second Sun.

climbs.name: Black Magic
climbs.fa: Rob Robinson, Clint Henley, Peter Henley - 1981

content.description:
First pitch- Up through overhanging blocks split by a crack. I bypassed all this nonsense by jug hauling to the right. Next part of the pitch is very dirty. 

  Second Pitch- From bolted anchors up and right over a roof on tough finger locks. I never saw a pin anywhere. Up blank face and under a perfect hand crack splitting a big roof. Jam and then jug haul to the top. 

  The second pitch is what you're doing this route for. Dont be detered by the dirty first pitch.
content.protection: Up to #3 camalot. Small cams for start of second pitch
content.location: On the Black Magic Buttress; starts 30' right of Trailside Trials.

content.description: Just left of the second pitch of Black Magic.  Follow shallow, flaring, pebbly, somewhat painful crack to upper face climbing and mantle onto the top.
content.protection: Standard Sunset rack with doubles in finger/hand sizes.  Two bolts/rings to left above off-width corner.
content.location: Starts left of P2 anchors, straight up through corner (crux) before gaining crack.

content.description: A bouldery start with very little protection makes the start of this climb interesting.  Boulder up past thin holds to a good horizontal.  Put in a bomber piece and breathe.  Continue up and right past horizontals and crimpy flakes to the base of a crack.  Jam and layback this pumpy crack to the top.
content.protection: Rap rings.  Trad gear.
content.location: On the back side of Celebrity Flake (Train Time, etc), up hill off the trail.

climbs.name: Armadillo’s Revenge
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by V Draper J Hollada, 2019

content.description: Same start as Armadillo. On the ledge above the wide crack, traverse right about ten feet into a flake system and follow it to top.
content.protection: Standard rack. Slings and biners on tree at the top.
content.location: Same as Armadillo, variation to follow the nice features on the face

climbs.name: Armadillo
climbs.fa: Unknown, cleaned and documented by V Draper, J Hollada 2019

content.description:
This is an area we've dubbed the RoadKill Buttress, it's a tasty buffet filled with a whole heaping helping of easy to moderate southern-fried sandstone.  Fill up on wide cracks mixed with incut plates, face climbing and all around fun moves with good protection. Belly up if you're hankering for some easier climbing without the usual sandbags attached.

 On the starting ledge towards the middle of the face, look up to see a wider crack that passes a big blob of moss and a small tree.  Follow this obvious crack and then a bit of chimney as you make your way to the top.
content.protection: Mid-size to large cams, otherwise standard rack. Slings and biners on tree at the top.
content.location: Above the main trail, scramble to the base of Anteater. Walk a few steps right and use the large bent tree to hop down to a wide, grassy ledge. The following collection of easy routes start along this face that runs parallel to the trail far below.

content.description: Alternate start to Anteater. Follow broken crack system in the face to the large ledge, finish on upper half of Anteater.
content.protection: This alternate avoids the off width lower section of Anteater, don't need the big stuff.
content.location: To the right of Anteater, step down and around the corner, start on the face just right of the arete.

content.description:
Another stop on the Sunset sandbag tour. This is probably the best 5.6 in the state. Just be ready for that section of 5.9... 

  Climb a wide crack in a corner up to a large ledge. From the ledge, two cracks lead up the left face. The right crack is in a corner, and seems like it might be old-school, grovely 5.6. The left crack leads off from the edge of the ledge and splits the face. 

  Guidebooks seem to indicate you're supposed to take the left crack, and we went that way because it looked awesome. The good news: it was awesome. The bad news: it goes at about 5.9. 

  Either way you go, you'll eventually arrive up and left at a nice ledge with an L-shaped tree on it. You could stop there, but why not go all the way? Move up and right on the exposed face and top out on the arete.
content.protection:
If you want to sew up the wide section down low, bring a #4 C4 and two #5s. It can be done with much less. Light rack for the rest. 

  No fixed anchor at the top. Be prepared to improvise.
content.location: Hiking down the trail past the Treasure Chest area (Dodge City et al.), after a few minutes you'll pass a short section of cliff next to the trail with an obvious cave in it. Backtrack and head up the eroded trail to the left of the cave to a ledge system up above the trail. Look for an obvious wide crack in a right-facing corner.

content.description: Climb the lower face located to the right side of the arete to a ledge.  From the ledge, work up both sides of the arete past horizontals, getting gear where you can until a nice rest on a big ledge, below a roof/bulge, before finishing up the last few feet via one of two ways:  step right and up a crack or straight up over the bulge.
content.protection: Standard rack, some thin stuff, runners.  Gear and Trees at the top can be used for anchors.  Rap from the Pigs ring anchors.
content.location: On the left side of the "Pigs Buttress"...you can't miss the arete.

content.description:
One of Sunset's few true novice leads, Airbrush is a great choice for a new trad leader.  Protection is ample, so sew it up.  Also a good toprope for beginners. 

  Scramble up past ledges, then climb some easy crack/flake systems, finishing on a slabby section to the top.
content.protection: Mostly small to medium gear (up to about 2").  Build a gear anchor at the top; rap from a slung tree with rap rings.
content.location: Starts near the far end of Sunset South, about 200' past Blonde Ambition and 15' right of Terminal Impatience.

content.description: Conquer a small roof using undercling and hidden crimp, get a short rest in a perfect fingers deep hand jam.  Proceed upward to right side of cave and anchors overhead. Sustained and pumpy.
content.protection: Small cams protect the opening crux, mix of finger sized cams and stoppers for crack.  Two bolt anchor with rings.
content.location: 15' right of Dreamway, in alcove above trail before Wind Walker/Liberty Bell area.

content.description: Great route! If you love awesome moves, this is the route for you. Good moves below roof lead to jugs above roof. Start just right of Afternoon Delight. Climb the face past a bolt below roof. Pull the small roof and countinue up the face with jugs.
content.protection: Nuts and TCUs or cams up to .75. Ring anchors.
content.location: Located on Celeberity Flake  five feet right of Afternoon Delight. 20 min hike.

content.description:
Afternoon Delight isn't as well known as Blonde Ambition, but it's one of the great moderates at Sunset nevertheless.  Pumpy for the grade, it has plentiful protection and makes a nice warmup for the harder lines in the Celebrity Flake area. 

  Starting just right of the Jug Mania arete, move up the face through sometimes-slopy holds to a bulge.  Climb through the bulge using one of two cracks, then continue up to a prominent crack system.  Follow the crack to the top.
content.protection: Takes mostly medium gear, up to #2 Camalot or equivalent.  Ring anchors at the top.
content.location: Starts just right of Jug Mania near the left end of the Celebrity Flake outcropping.

content.description: Follow a thin crack and steep left facing corner.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #2 camalot, rap from trees
content.location: Next section of wall right of Blonde Ambition just before obvious arete.  Route follows a left facing dihedral about halfway up.

content.description: This section tends to have less crowds, but some of the finest routes at Sunset.  Don't miss Wind Walker (5.9), Blonde Ambition (5.7) and Train Time (5.10a).
